commit_message:
extend_volume method fails if volume size is float

RSD driver method fails when float volume size is passed to the
extend_volume method. Fixed this bug by casting size_in_gb to int

Change-Id: I7c0abd7ff0bcb620b3e686885e7e6f04b9f9a519
Closes-Bug: #1838714

commit_message:
test_l3: Be a bit more selective where to inject a failiure

Instead of blindly making the first publish() fail.

Remove assumptions about how many publish() calls are made.

These problems were exposed by the recent change. [1]

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/638274/

Closes-Bug: #1839246
Change-Id: I40a8a3905435233e6c00c5439df287db5ab10ed6

commit_message:
Re-enable the py36 tox environment

A recent automated patch[1] removed py36 from the tox default
environment list. Since Ubuntu 18.04 includes python 3.6 and we
still include a functional-3.6 test, we should keep the py36
environment in the list.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/669440/

Change-Id: I2bab434523efee0ad755e794f00c3a1ca85ec68f

commit_message:
Fix var src_extra_specs error

This error was discovered by tool coverity. If we don't
initialize this var src_extra_specs, line 225 may sometimes
raise an error.

Change-Id: I992b56b64d56f35c8355b22707c3db5112964b31

commit_message:
Add octavia-v2-dsvm jobs to the gate queue

Octavia is a standalone project and supports the LBaaSv2.
We should be gating on octavia-v2-dsvm jobs in stable/rocky.

Change-Id: If0eb6e934e8bfb6759c61db3f1f1b89fe02264eb

subject: Updates glance config to honor documented default paste_deploy
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 5314, 'name': 'Brian Rosmaita', 'email': 'rosmaita.fossdev@gmail.com', 'username': 'brian-rosmaita'}, {'_account_id': 9008, 'name': 'VMware NSX CI', 'username': 'vmwareminesweeper', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 10068, 'name': 'Welcome, new contributor!', 'username': 'welcome-message'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 15804, 'name': 'Ghezal', 'email': 'ghezal.sherdil@gmail.com', 'username': 'ghezal'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23561, 'name': 'iain MacDonnell', 'email': 'iain.macdonnell@oracle.com', 'username': 'imacdonn'}, {'_account_id': 29380, 'name': 'Michael Moore', 'email': 'openstack@mdmoore.me', 'username': 'mdmoore'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 29380, 'date': '2018-10-26 19:16:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-10-26 19:16:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 15804, 'date': '2018-10-26 19:59:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

+1'}, {'account_id': 23561, 'date': '2018-10-26 21:19:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Looks like sample_default was added in [1]. I do wonder if it was chosen deliberately (instead of "default")

[1] https://github.com/openstack/glance/commit/afb18df869946a4a1175fc20268417671da7dcf3'}, {'account_id': 29380, 'date': '2018-10-26 21:28:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 23561, 'date': '2018-10-26 22:00:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29380, 'date': '2018-10-26 22:05:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 29380, 'date': '2018-10-26 22:06:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 23561, 'date': '2018-10-26 22:08:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

This may warrant a release-note too, since it's actually changing the default behaviour, even though it's changing it to what the docs say it should be. I'll let the core team decide if it's needed..."}, {'account_id': 29380, 'date': '2018-10-26 22:10:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Published edit on patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 23561, 'date': '2018-10-26 22:14:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

Makes sense to me. Core reviewers should decide if release-note needed.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-11-05 21:09:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Michael, thanks for picking this up.

In etc/glance-api-paste.ini, no auth or image caching is defined as the default (this is the pipeline that corresponds to an empty setting for paste_deploy.flavor).  Thus the problem here isn't that the incorrect default is specified, but that the sample_default is displayed in a misleading way by the config file generator.  A fix for that has been merged: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/607353/

The default value for paste_deploy.flavor most likely hasn't changed since Bexar, so I don't think it's a good idea to change it now.  But I agree that the generated config doc/file are misleading, so a good fix for this bug is to update the glance requirements.txt and lower-constraints.txt as soon as the change mentioned above has been released in oslo.config.  Also, I would not object if you were to revise the help text in config.py to mention that if you don't set an explicit value for the option, the default is "no auth or image caching".'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-08-07 12:10:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Is this still needed? Please abandon if no further changes are necessary.'}, {'account_id': 29380, 'date': '2019-08-08 02:30:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Is this still needed? Please abandon if no further changes are
 > necessary.

Based on comment from Brian it's been taken care of in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/607353/  so I'll mark abandoned"}, {'account_id': 29380, 'date': '2019-08-08 02:31:11.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

as mentioned by Brian, resolved in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/607353/'}]

commit_message:
Updates glance config to honor documented default paste_deploy

Updates glance config to use the documented default value 'keystone' for paste_deploy

Change-Id: I10979ac996196ea4b8ff632d52f9d323d3c1fca4
Closes-Bug: 1799588

[{'created': '2019-02-19 12:35:35.000000000', 'message': 'Add configuration item cpu_models to libvirt

Add configuration item: `cpu_models`, an ordered list of CPU list of CPU
models the host supports. It is expected that the list is ordered so that
the more common and less advanced CPU models are listed earlier. The
reported cpu feature traits will be the union of features of all the cpu
models.

This requires `cpu_mode` set to `custom`. `cpu_model_extra_flags` should
be compatible with all models in the `cpu_models` list. If both
`cpu_models` and `cpu_model` are set, `cpu_model` will be ignored.

commit_message:
Select cpu model from a list of cpu models

Add configuration item: `cpu_model_list`, an ordered list of CPU models
the host supports. Older configuration item `cpu_model` is deprecated.

Add a precheck method when service starts: check if the configuration
`cpu_mode` and `cpu_model_list` is correct and the compatibility
between `cpu_model`, `cpu_model_extra_flags` and host cpu by using
host.compare_cpu()

Change the method of report cpu traits, the reported cpu feature traits
will be the union of features of all the cpu models and host cpu when
`cpu_mode` is `custom`.

Change the method of generate guest cpu xml, if the `cpu_mode` is set
to custom, and set the trait in flavor, libvirt driver will select
first matching CPU model in the `cpu_model_list`, if no trait set,
libvirt driver will select the first CPU model in the `cpu_model_list`.

Change-Id: I7ed7ca80c4b553a1a4429febac9461bad7598bac
Implements: blueprint cpu-model-selection

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-31 13:44:47.000000000', 'message': "Don't generate service UUID for deleted services

In Pike, we added a UUID field to services and during an upgrade from
Ocata => Pike, when instances are accessed joined with their associated
services, we generate a UUID for the services on-the-fly.

This causes a problem in the scenario where an operator upgrades their
cluster and has old, deleted services with hostnames matching existing
services associated with instances. When we go to generate the service
UUID for the old, deleted service, we hit a ServiceTooOld exception.

This addresses the problem by not bothering to generate a UUID for a
deleted service. One alternative would be to exclude deleted services
when we join the 'instances' and 'services' tables, but I'm not sure
whether that approach might cause unintended effects where service
information that used to be viewable for instances becomes hidden.

Closes-Bug: #1778305
Closes-Bug: #1764556

Change-Id: I347096a527c257075cefe7b81210622f6cd87daf
(cherry picked from commit 16e163053ca39886f11fdb8a3af10a28619fc105)
"}, {'created': '2019-08-07 21:04:07.000000000', 'message': "Don't generate service UUID for deleted services

In Pike, we added a UUID field to services and during an upgrade from
Ocata => Pike, when instances are accessed joined with their associated
services, we generate a UUID for the services on-the-fly.

This causes a problem in the scenario where an operator upgrades their
cluster and has old, deleted services with hostnames matching existing
services associated with instances. When we go to generate the service
UUID for the old, deleted service, we hit a ServiceTooOld exception.

This addresses the problem by not bothering to generate a UUID for a
deleted service. One alternative would be to exclude deleted services
when we join the 'instances' and 'services' tables, but I'm not sure
whether that approach might cause unintended effects where service
information that used to be viewable for instances becomes hidden.

Closes-Bug: #1778305
Closes-Bug: #1764556

Change-Id: I347096a527c257075cefe7b81210622f6cd87daf
(cherry picked from commit 16e163053ca39886f11fdb8a3af10a28619fc105)
"}]
commit_message:
Don't generate service UUID for deleted services

In Pike, we added a UUID field to services and during an upgrade from
Ocata => Pike, when instances are accessed joined with their associated
services, we generate a UUID for the services on-the-fly.

This causes a problem in the scenario where an operator upgrades their
cluster and has old, deleted services with hostnames matching existing
services associated with instances. When we go to generate the service
UUID for the old, deleted service, we hit a ServiceTooOld exception.

This addresses the problem by not bothering to generate a UUID for a
deleted service. One alternative would be to exclude deleted services
when we join the 'instances' and 'services' tables, but I'm not sure
whether that approach might cause unintended effects where service
information that used to be viewable for instances becomes hidden.

Closes-Bug: #1778305
Closes-Bug: #1764556

Change-Id: I347096a527c257075cefe7b81210622f6cd87daf
(cherry picked from commit 16e163053ca39886f11fdb8a3af10a28619fc105)

commit_message:
Add remove_service to token fixtures

SDK is going to start using these Token fixtures to programmatically
create fake service catalogs in the test suite containing entries
for everything in service-types-authority.

In order to be able to test code paths where some service does not
exist, it would be good to be able to just remove a service from
the catalog, instead of needing to construct a full new one from
scratch.

Change-Id: I4b5469aefbe9b91c125da482509cdc627faa5525

commit_message:
Separate tripleo-time into two distinct roles

This change converts the tripleo time role into two roles:

  - tripleo-ptp
  - tripleo-timezone

This change will ensure we're able to cleanly install and setup
ptp when needed while also providing a well defined interface
for setting the timezone on systems.

Change-Id: I0a2b2241a38f3d98ac421e6106fb81210961c1f5
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
docs: clarify nova migration-list --host option

The GET /os-migrations API takes both a host and
source_compute filter parameter. The former filters
on either the source or destination compute, so this
change clarifies that in the command help for the
--host option.

Change-Id: I078add63896c7455be7e3672b7172debb962a5e2

commit_message:
Add basic client implementation for sbus protocol

This patch introduces basic implementation of the client to communicate
with remote process using sbus, to gather all codes which deeply depend
on the sbus protocol into the one place.

This patch also introduces sbus CLI, which enables operators to send
sbus command like halt easily.

Change-Id: Ie1721c016b10b6562b131eb39e3dc84b1d8d473f

commit_message:
Support connecting OVN DB over SSL

This patch introduce parameters which support using SSL to connect to
OVN_Northbound DB and OVN_Southbound DB.

Change-Id: I5a03a74e68d2b8b7364341ba2ed77dfb419ebc58
Signed-off-by: Kamil Sambor <ksambor@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ic9824657bafafdabda7fe3a983c5fee37f7981d7

commit_message:
Fixed containers-build role to compare built containers

Since podman is not installed by default in containers-build job
so the Built var is returning zero and further giving
[: -l: binary operator expected error.

In order to fix the above issue, It adds task
to set proper container_cli and reuse buildah and docker
and compare the build containers status using returncode.

Use sudo while cating the files as buildah is runned via
sudo and it will fix permission issue.

Change-Id: I61cd114ec7150d2c6156c5d8a2fe105fdd458348
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix up stable gate

This is a combination of three commits from master:

---

Isolate docs requirements

...since modern sphinx won't install on py27.

While we're at it, clean up some warnings and treat warnings as errors.

Also, fix up how we parse test configs so we can run func tests.

Related-Change: Id3c2ed87230c5918c18e2c01d086df8157f036b1
(cherry picked from commit 113eacf3b80f61d366b3e95b558b40f82ff728a4)

---

Drag forward prettytable in lower-constraints

Apparently version 0.7 got unpublished recently.

(cherry picked from commit 5bd66947fc3d8987d4b24d5119a346031004229e)

---

docs: Clean up formatting

(cherry-picked from commit 7563d9cb5642c85a31708fd863e2737f9d6c9419)

---

Change-Id: I3c6bca460ee5ff99195495a29e8b8bbf4ed804ff
(cherry picked from commit 172aa9016977a3b03f07da0350c6aa9ade1e55a0)

commit_message:
config: disable notifications by default

We are currently pushing out notifications even if Ceilometer is
not enabled resulting in huge queues.  Let's not do that.

Change-Id: Id4a70270d4032ff1c3f0089360e897e5c82c394b
(cherry picked from commit 752f261ab6dc986ca1e9b0f16189f20d7ab8a15d)

commit_message:
pcs 0.10: authenticate nodes before adding them to the cluster

With pcs 0.10 and RHEL/CentOS 8, every node that needs to be
added into a running cluster muste be authenticated first in pcsd.

So when replacing a cluster node or automatically scaling up the
cluster, make sure that we run a "pcs host auth" command prior to
any "pcs cluster node add".

Change-Id: I88c1188b2202e0cf70b82db629c3dd748ad01bf3
Closes-Bug: #1839209

commit_message:
Improve docs and comments for provider_ids_from_rp_ids

When the double join was removed from provider_ids_from_rp_ids [1]
it became clear that additional docs and commentary were required
to avoid future confusion over why the new way of using it will
work. This adds it.

[1] If937053a8af3f0eecdd90aa807be0abc316d8c4f

Change-Id: I4958ba0b208ca457e049875433dc0826eaab8795

commit_message:
Clean up the extend_usages_by_provider_tree method

In review of the change [1] that created
extend_usages_by_provider_tree some issues with the docs and the
layout of the code were identified. This change attempts to address
them:

* Doc comment on self.usages updated to show more of the content.

* The SQL-half of the extend_usages_by_provider_tree method is
  extracted to its own function.

[1] I5d05d15d33beb1622a06bde0e32c3f52ba01b448

Change-Id: I79dac6c83d9c118bd6a66cdc3cd300c3c12af538

commit_message:
Fix snapshot condition error

When run_snapshot_tests==false but CONF.share.capability_create
_share_from_snapshot_support==true, resource_setup() makes no
cls.shares[1] and cls.snap. Check both conditions to make sure
object exists.

Change-Id: I5507295baa85bdf911732309d6c1876dc0d5a559

This patches adds the possibility to deactivate in-flight validations by
skipping the "opendev-validation" ansible tag.

commit_message:
Allows to disable in-flight validations

This patches adds the possibility to deactivate in-flight validations by
skipping the "opendev-validation" ansible tag.

It does it in a generic way, meaning we might pass other tags to skip.

Change-Id: I6f3e4fb279146a0f292818929092d1aeb1d3fced

No need to specify this as kolla adds this arg automatically
when using kolla_start.

[{'created': '2019-08-06 14:52:22.000000000', 'message': 'Add ceph-ansible support to tripleo-ansible-inventory

The tripleo-ansible-inventory command produces an inventory
which works with TripleO but not with ceph-ansible. TripleO
ceph-ansible integration then creates its own inventory for
the ceph-ansible playbook run. This patch makes generating
a separate inventory for ceph-ansible no longer necessary.

TripleO services already map to the same inventory groups
used by ceph-ansible, e.g. ceph_clients:clients, ceph_mons:
mons, ceph_osds:osds, etc. This patch maps the names of the

groups used by ceph-ansible and creates a duplicate group

expects.

Change-Id: Ie9880d7b6702b3c5f0e407e4ffe6f297912a1d10
(cherry picked from commit 3f48630791f5051b97afba1365d8f5defb797951)
'}]
commit_message:
Add ceph-ansible support to tripleo-ansible-inventory

The tripleo-ansible-inventory command produces an inventory
which works with TripleO but not with ceph-ansible. TripleO
ceph-ansible integration then creates its own inventory for
the ceph-ansible playbook run. This patch makes generating
a separate inventory for ceph-ansible no longer necessary.

TripleO services already map to the same inventory groups
used by ceph-ansible, e.g. ceph_clients:clients, ceph_mons:
mons, ceph_osds:osds, etc. This patch maps the names of the
TripleO inventory Ceph groups to the names of the inventory
groups used by ceph-ansible and creates a duplicate group
entry in the inventory, but with the names that ceph-ansible
expects.

Change-Id: Ie9880d7b6702b3c5f0e407e4ffe6f297912a1d10
(cherry picked from commit 3f48630791f5051b97afba1365d8f5defb797951)

commit_message:
tox: Keeping going with docs

Sphinx 1.8 introduced [1] the '--keep-going' argument which, as its name
suggests, keeps the build running when it encounters non-fatal errors.
This is exceptionally useful in avoiding a continuous edit-build loop
when undertaking large doc reworks where multiple errors may be
introduced.

[1] https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/commit/e3483e9b045

Change-Id: Idc38751e1629947f5842651d99b1528f74247b42
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix up stable gate

This is a combination of three commits from master:

---

Isolate docs requirements

...since modern sphinx won't install on py27.

While we're at it, clean up some warnings and treat warnings as errors.

Also, fix up how we parse test configs so we can run func tests.

Related-Change: Id3c2ed87230c5918c18e2c01d086df8157f036b1
(cherry picked from commit 113eacf3b80f61d366b3e95b558b40f82ff728a4)

---

Drag forward prettytable in lower-constraints

Apparently version 0.7 got unpublished recently.

(cherry picked from commit 5bd66947fc3d8987d4b24d5119a346031004229e)

---

docs: Clean up formatting

(cherry-picked from commit 7563d9cb5642c85a31708fd863e2737f9d6c9419)

---

Change-Id: I3c6bca460ee5ff99195495a29e8b8bbf4ed804ff

This changes gabbits/nested-perfload.yaml to create a tree of
providers based on the NUMANetworkFixture used in the functional
tests. For the time being only one type of compute node is created
(of which there will be 1000 instances).

The resulting hierarchy has 7 resource providers.

The allocation candidates query is:

commit_message:
Implement a more complex nested-perfload topology

This changes gabbits/nested-perfload.yaml to create a tree of
providers based on one of the compute nodes in the NUMANetworkFixture
used in the functional tests. For the time being only one type of
compute node is created (of which there will be 1000 instances).
Room is left for future expansion as requirements expand.

The resulting hierarchy has 7 resource providers.

The allocation candidates query is:

GET /allocation_candidates?
    resources=DISK_GB:10&
    required=COMPUTE_VOLUME_MULTI_ATTACH&
    resources_COMPUTE=VCPU:1,MEMORY_MB:256&
    required_COMPUTE=CUSTOM_FOO&
    resources_FPGA=FPGA:1&
    group_policy=none&
    same_subtree=_COMPUTE,_FPGA

This is a step in the right direction but is not yet a complete
exercising of all the nested functionality. It is, however, more
complex than prior, notably testing 'same_subtree'. We should
continue to iterate to get it doing more.

Change-Id: I67d8091b464cd7b875b37766f52818a5a2faa780
Story: 2005443
Task: 35669

commit_message:
Add functional regression test for bug 1778305

This tests the scenario where an operator has upgraded from Ocata =>
Pike but has old, deleted services that share the same hostname with
currently existing, running services. The current behavior is that
ServiceTooOld is raised when we try to generate a UUID for the old,
deleted service while querying for a list of instances. After the bug
is fixed, we should be able to successfully query for a list of
instances.

Related-Bug: #1778305

Change-Id: I1c62a0a5be6c44176b5714af00cc181eb5437585
(cherry picked from commit 1d9aaef3d1c880b02d6b7c186e8de79cbaac9ae0)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-31 13:39:14.000000000', 'message': 'Add functional recreate test for bug 1764556

This attempts to recreate the following scenario:

1) boot instance on ocata host where the compute service
   does not have a uuid
2) migrate instance
3) delete the ocata service (thus deleting the compute node)
4) start compute service with the same name
5) migrate instance to newly-created compute node
6) upgrade to pike where services.uuid data migration happens
7) list instances as admin to join on the services table

The failure occurs when listing instances because the deleted
service with the same name as the compute host that the instance
is running on gets pulled from the DB and the Service object
attempts to set a uuid on it, which fails since it's not using
a read_deleted="yes" context.

While working on this, the service_get_all_by_binary DB API
method had to be fixed to not hard-code read_deleted="no" since
the test needs to be able to read deleted services, which it can
control via its own context object (note that
RequestContext.read_deleted already defaults to "no" so the
hard-coding in the DB API is unnecessarily restrictive).

NOTE(mriedem): This backport needed to use the set_nodes/restore_nodes
methods on the fake virt module since change
I2cf2fcbaebc706f897ce5dfbff47d32117064f9c is not in Stein.

Change-Id: I4d60da26fcf0a77628d1fdf4e818884614fa4f02
Related-Bug: #1764556
(cherry picked from commit 81f05f53d357a546c7f9a53cae6ef45b92e28bc1)
'}]
commit_message:
Add functional recreate test for bug 1764556

This attempts to recreate the following scenario:

1) boot instance on ocata host where the compute service
   does not have a uuid
2) migrate instance
3) delete the ocata service (thus deleting the compute node)
4) start compute service with the same name
5) migrate instance to newly-created compute node
6) upgrade to pike where services.uuid data migration happens
7) list instances as admin to join on the services table

The failure occurs when listing instances because the deleted
service with the same name as the compute host that the instance
is running on gets pulled from the DB and the Service object
attempts to set a uuid on it, which fails since it's not using
a read_deleted="yes" context.

While working on this, the service_get_all_by_binary DB API
method had to be fixed to not hard-code read_deleted="no" since
the test needs to be able to read deleted services, which it can
control via its own context object (note that
RequestContext.read_deleted already defaults to "no" so the
hard-coding in the DB API is unnecessarily restrictive).

NOTE(mriedem): This backport needed to use the set_nodes/restore_nodes
methods on the fake virt module since change
I2cf2fcbaebc706f897ce5dfbff47d32117064f9c is not in Stein.

Change-Id: I4d60da26fcf0a77628d1fdf4e818884614fa4f02
Related-Bug: #1764556
(cherry picked from commit 81f05f53d357a546c7f9a53cae6ef45b92e28bc1)

commit_message:
Update docutils with 0.15.1

docutils 0.15 breaks the pep8 tests with error:
"ImportError: cannot import name nodes" (as in mentioned bug).
Fix available in  0.15.1 , So updating version with the same.

Closes-Bug:#1837741

Change-Id: I8fc85b8ee8239ea216702b2e261455a6f68707a2

[{'created': '2019-07-31 05:36:29.000000000', 'message': "Define new exceptions related to device profiles and ARQs.

These exceptions are parametrized to log additional info.
Example:
    raise exception.AcceleratorRequestOpFailed(
        op='retrieve',
        param='instance %s' % instance_uuid)
should produce:
    Accelerator Request (ARQ): failed to retrieve for instance <uuid>

"}, {'created': '2019-08-01 03:30:56.000000000', 'message': "Define new exceptions related to device profiles and ARQs.

These exceptions are parametrized to log additional info.
Example:
    raise exception.AcceleratorRequestOpFailed(
        op='retrieve',
        param='instance %s' % instance_uuid)
should produce:
    Accelerator Request (ARQ): failed to retrieve for instance <uuid>

Change-Id: I11755edf2a48ce3bc8f6207df6e8535d50b9c89e
Blueprint: nova-cyborg-interaction
"}]
commit_message:
Define new exceptions related to device profiles and ARQs.

These exceptions are parametrized to log additional info.
Example:
    raise exception.AcceleratorRequestOpFailed(
        op='retrieve',
        param='instance %s' % instance_uuid)
should produce:
    Accelerator Request (ARQ): failed to retrieve for instance <uuid>

Change-Id: I11755edf2a48ce3bc8f6207df6e8535d50b9c89e
Blueprint: nova-cyborg-interaction

commit_message:
service_setup: refactor service setup to a single file

This patch refactors the openstack user/service/endpoints creation to
service_setup.yml which will eventually be managed by
openstack-ansible-tests.

Change-Id: Ic126b9ad6fa4905514f356b98690e04965f4d93c

Ensure "rabbit_use_ssl" is specified in the [oslo_messaging_rabbit]
config section instead of "ssl" for Ocata, since "ssl" was not yet
introduced.

This is fixed by using section-oslo-messaging-rabbit for pike and
above rather than ocata and above, thus reverting back to using
section-rabbitmq-oslo for ocata.

Change-Id: I81ce8f745542625897f353f0b2560a695e74a3ea
Closes-Bug: #1838696
'}]
commit_message:
Revert back to using "rabbit_use_ssl" for ocata

Ensure "rabbit_use_ssl" is specified in the [oslo_messaging_rabbit]
config section instead of "ssl" for Ocata, since "ssl" was not yet
introduced.

This is fixed by using section-oslo-messaging-rabbit for pike and
above rather than ocata and above, thus reverting back to using
section-rabbitmq-oslo for ocata.

Change-Id: I81ce8f745542625897f353f0b2560a695e74a3ea
Closes-Bug: #1838696

Fix a call to _iscsiadm_update() in which a list was being passed as
the target_iqn connection property.  This property is used directly as

Fix a call to _iscsiadm_update() in which a list was being passed as

commit_message:
Fix bad argument to iscsiadm in iSCSI discovery

Fix a call to _iscsiadm_update() in which a list was being passed as
the target_iqn connection property.  This property is used directly as
an argument to the iscsiadm -T option, so it must be a plain string.

Change-Id: I9c2ff1de1f89fb49dd6c5a90679d5c4238d5476a
Closes-bug: 1838820

subject: Prevent UDP LBs to use different IP protocol versions in amphora driver
messages:
[{'account_id': 29244, 'date': '2019-07-02 07:01:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 29244, 'date': '2019-07-02 09:50:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-07-02 14:58:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Backport-Candidate+1 Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Looks good, just needs better unit test coverage and a release notes update.'}, {'account_id': 29244, 'date': '2019-07-03 06:52:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 29244, 'date': '2019-07-03 06:53:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-07-03 15:04:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Backport-Candidate+2 Code-Review+2

LGTM'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2019-07-05 16:22:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I'm dubious that this is a complete enough solution. This is one way for this to happen, but it's a significantly more complex issue than this patch makes it seem. You can still add a pool with existing mixed members to a new listener, and you can still batch-update a list of mixed members. IMO merging this just slightly confuses the situation without actually resolving it."}, {'account_id': 29244, 'date': '2019-07-08 08:16:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Workflow-1

> I'm dubious that this is a complete enough solution. This is one
 > way for this to happen, but it's a significantly more complex issue
 > than this patch makes it seem. You can still add a pool with
 > existing mixed members to a new listener, and you can still
 > batch-update a list of mixed members. IMO merging this just
 > slightly confuses the situation without actually resolving it.

I agree for batch-update of members, but I don't find any other missing cases:
- a pool is created with UDP protocol, it cannot have mixed members
- an existing UDP pool might be added to a new listener but the listener have to be part of the same LB as the existing listener (so it uses the same subnet - for now), so we cannot mix IPv4 and IPv6"}, {'account_id': 29244, 'date': '2019-07-08 11:57:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2019-08-03 00:23:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

OK, well, this is definitely better than what we have now. If there's other cases that still bypass this validation, we can fix them when we see them. :)"}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-08-07 18:03:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Backport-Candidate+2 Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-02 07:01:24.000000000', 'message': "Prevent UDP LBs to use different IP protocol versions in amphora driver

The amphora doesn't support mixing IPv4 and IPv6 addresses for its
members and its VIP when using UDP load balancers.
This commit adds a validation step to ensure that IP protocol versions
are the same in a UDP LB in the amphora driver.

Story: 2005876
Task: 33689

members and its VIP when using UDP load balancers.
This commit adds a validation step in the member_create and th e
member_batch_update functions of the amphora driver to ensure that IP
protocol versions are the same in a UDP load balancer.

Story: 2005876
Task: 33689

Change-Id: If6fb3fde9b43ac82af46eaddc48ec7a3a5b95602
"}]
commit_message:
Prevent UDP LBs to use different IP protocol versions in amphora driver

The amphora doesn't support mixing IPv4 and IPv6 addresses for its
members and its VIP when using UDP load balancers.
This commit adds a validation step in the member_create and th e
member_batch_update functions of the amphora driver to ensure that IP
protocol versions are the same in a UDP load balancer.

Story: 2005876
Task: 33689

Change-Id: If6fb3fde9b43ac82af46eaddc48ec7a3a5b95602

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-08 09:07:58.000000000', 'message': 'Configure supplemental node firewall for FreeIPA ports

The supplemental node that is used for deploying FreeIPA does not
configure the firewall to allow traffic to its required ports.  This
has not been a problem thus far, but the supplemental node is being
expanded to also run Keycloak for the purpose of enabling Keystone
to use it for OpenID Connect or SAML based federation.  The ansible
role that will be used to deploy Keycloak (nkinder.keycloak) will
configure firewalld for the Keycloak ports, which results in blocking
access to any of the FreeIPA services by other nodes such as the
undercloud.

This patch configures firewalld on the supplemental node to allow
traffic into the FreeIPA ports when deploying FreeIPA.

Change-Id: I6fa5ebee8a4cbcc65b78654072a6102b742d8b9c
'}]
commit_message:
Configure supplemental node firewall for FreeIPA ports

The supplemental node that is used for deploying FreeIPA does not
configure the firewall to allow traffic to its required ports.  This
has not been a problem thus far, but the supplemental node is being
expanded to also run Keycloak for the purpose of enabling Keystone
to use it for OpenID Connect or SAML based federation.  The ansible
role that will be used to deploy Keycloak (nkinder.keycloak) will
configure firewalld for the Keycloak ports, which results in blocking
access to any of the FreeIPA services by other nodes such as the
undercloud.

This patch configures firewalld on the supplemental node to allow
traffic into the FreeIPA ports when deploying FreeIPA.

Change-Id: I6fa5ebee8a4cbcc65b78654072a6102b742d8b9c

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-19 19:38:04.000000000', 'message': 'Use vlans for isolation for featureset039

Using the "multiple-nics" network isolation type does not work
properly when using featureset039 in a OOOQ virthost environment.
This changes the network isolation type to use VLANs.  This also
requires using 192.168.23.0/24 as the external network to avoid
networking conflicts with the created VLANs.

Change-Id: Id38b54997d95c18096f5e5e6db7f150398275735
'}]
commit_message:
Use vlans for isolation for featureset039

Using the "multiple-nics" network isolation type does not work
properly when using featureset039 in a OOOQ virthost environment.
This changes the network isolation type to use VLANs.  This also
requires using 192.168.23.0/24 as the external network to avoid
networking conflicts with the created VLANs.

Change-Id: Id38b54997d95c18096f5e5e6db7f150398275735

commit_message:
Add ability  to deploy FreeIPA on OVB

Modifies existing OVB deployment flow to allow for FreeIPA role
execution on a supplemental node prior to undercloud installation.

Depends-On: I6be62dc60b6bb383e1a43dc782bb6ba7c3b205dd
Change-Id: Idfd77716b0e9e49385b5ae952dc168821934676a

(6 comments)

This is a good first start. I'd like to see some molecule tests, and common structure setup around this role. Please have a look here: https://docs.openstack.org/tripleo-ansible/latest/contributing.html#create-a-new-role-with-automation on adding a new role using our basic tooling. revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-08 12:38:14.000000000', 'message': 'Add playbook to stop containers

We need to stop several containers on the upgrades workflow.

This submission allows to reduce the duplicated code in THT.
It also handles the case in which we have podman as the CLI
but the containers running with docker.

Change-Id: I4fcc0858cac8f59d797d62f6de18c02e4b1819dc

commit_message:
Add playbook to stop containers

We need to stop several containers on the upgrades workflow.

This submission allows to reduce the duplicated code in THT.
It also handles the case in which we have podman as the CLI
but the containers running with docker.

Change-Id: I4fcc0858cac8f59d797d62f6de18c02e4b1819dc

LGTM, and I'm hoping that can be ported back to Rocky to simplify the dependency chain there."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-09-21 12:44:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

I think this would pass testing, but would it work on production?

The driver itself is requiring ceilometer unconditionally (which is something that I suppose could get improved) here: https://github.com/openstack/networking-odl/blob/ecde0a165f6145d8257fd52d50ee6f417b0b6ff0/networking_odl/ceilometer/network/statistics/opendaylight_v2/driver.py#L19-L20'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-09-21 12:45:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

I think it's a good patch, but like I said in previous comment, it's probably incomplete."}, {'account_id': 21883, 'date': '2018-09-23 17:31:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> I think it's a good patch, but like I said in previous comment,
 > it's probably incomplete.

As far as I understood, that driver is only loaded in case neutron.conf includes the config: network.statistics.drivers =
opendaylight.v2 as stated in the entry points: https://github.com/openstack/networking-odl/blob/master/setup.cfg#L57-L58. Therefore, the user who wants that functionality needs to change neutron.conf and, after this patch, install networking-odl[ceilometer]. Therefore, I think it will work in production"}, {'account_id': 26507, 'date': '2018-10-03 12:47:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2

LGTM, I'd actually prefer to remove the ceilometer driver completely but this could be a good first step"}, {'account_id': 21883, 'date': '2018-10-03 15:15:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 17120, 'date': '2018-10-03 17:14:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 20866, 'date': '2018-10-04 11:30:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Do we have a functional deployment including this patch just to be sure that it works before merging it.'}, {'account_id': 26507, 'date': '2018-10-04 12:11:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

> Do we have a functional deployment including this patch just to be
 > sure that it works before merging it.

This is actually a great point. This should be covered by the functional CI jobs. Currently the functional are installing ceilometer (as per the tox.ini definition for the job).

We have two routes to follow. Either (1) we create another set of functional jobs that don't include ceilometer as part of the installation or (2) we just remove ceilometer from the current functional tests.

I prefer the 2nd route because I don't want to add more jobs to the CI (adding more load). The drawback it has is that functional tests won't be able to test functionality related to the ceilometer driver that n-odl. Since I favor removing that driver altogether I think that's not a drawback we can't live with.

I was actually hesitant with my previous +2 because I agree with evrard on what he previously mentioned and now with Janki's comment I have given a deeper thought to it. I now reflect with my -1 that we shouldn't land this until this is actually tested somehow and the how could be what I explained before. 

What do others think?"}, {'account_id': 21883, 'date': '2018-10-05 08:32:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

To follow the 2nd alternative you suggest, is it enough with removing the line: pip install -q -e "git+https://git.openstack.org/openstack/ceilometer#egg=ceilometer"? I'm not very familiar with how zuul tests are done'}, {'account_id': 21883, 'date': '2018-10-05 08:32:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 26507, 'date': '2018-10-08 09:07:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

 > functional jobs that don't include ceilometer as part of the
 > installation or (2) we just remove ceilometer from the current
 > functional tests.
 > 
 > I prefer the 2nd route because I don't want to add more jobs to the
 > CI (adding more load). The drawback it has is that functional tests
 > won't be able to test functionality related to the ceilometer
 > driver that n-odl. Since I favor removing that driver altogether I
 > think that's not a drawback we can't live with.
 > 
 > I was actually hesitant with my previous +2 because I agree with
 > evrard on what he previously mentioned and now with Janki's comment
 > I have given a deeper thought to it. I now reflect with my -1 that
 > we shouldn't land this until this is actually tested somehow and
 > the how could be what I explained before.
 > 
 > What do others think?
>
> To follow the 2nd alternative you suggest, is it enough with
> removing the line: pip install -q -e
> "git+https://git.openstack.org/openstack/ceilometer#egg=ceilometer"?
> I'm not very familiar with how zuul tests are done

For the functional tests you can see in tox.ini that it's including test-requirements.txt and tests/functional/requirements.txt Ceilometer is in test-requirements, which sounds logical because the same file is used for the unit test jobs, coverage, etc. but the thing is that for the functional we would prefer not to have them. 

The solution could be not include test-requirements.txt for the functional tox environment and add packages that might be needed to tests/functional/requirements.txt. I recommend doing this in a different patch that precedes this one.

Does this make things clearer?'}, {'account_id': 26507, 'date': '2018-10-08 09:07:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Use extras for ceilometer dependency

Ceilometer should only be installed when opendaylight_v2 is defined as
network.statistics.drivers. It does not make sense that ceilometer needs
to get installed any time we install networking-odl

Based on:

https://setuptools.readthedocs.io/en/latest/setuptools.html#declaring-extras

Taking as example:

https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/master/setup.cfg#L21-L29

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/611248/
Change-Id: I48d03d3113ee8383beec1d35520de79e34a1fec4
Signed-off-by: Manuel Buil <mbuil@suse.com>

commit_message:
rbd: start using active-active

This patch drops the hacky workaround of using backend_host which
is not recommended by the Cinder team and instead uses active-active
RBD which has been implemented since Rocky.

Closes-Bug: #1837403
Change-Id: I0c8aed4d0608c1f117e1baa1f428875956159ffd
(cherry picked from commit c148d77e29af6faebc1c9b012ae08aed447cd179)

Build succeeded.

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/674129/2 : SUCCESS in 2h 18m 38s'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-08-02 23:27:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

This is working. Follow req-fcc73e74-a929-4614-9dd6-7662d3320b67 from n-cpu [1] (where it is the request_id) to placement [2] (where it is the global_request_id.

What would be even nicer is if req-fcc73e74-a929-4614-9dd6-7662d3320b67 were the global_request_id on both sides. That's what the next patch should do for us.

But this is a big improvement from before, where you would have to track each request individually based on the placement-side (local) request_id it sent back.

[1] https://logs.opendev.org/29/674129/2/check/nova-live-migration/a15e47a/logs/screen-n-cpu.txt.gz#_Aug_02_03_40_04_133058
[2] https://logs.opendev.org/29/674129/2/check/nova-live-migration/a15e47a/logs/screen-placement-api.txt.gz#_Aug_02_03_40_04_472534"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-08-03 12:20:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(4 comments)

I'm not really sure what's wrong with using context.global_id if the context is coming from the compute API user request. The user can pass in a global request id and that should be stored on the context and passed throughout the services, that's the point of the work sdague did:

I6c56187f776602e0af88a368e41a4239901bde3e

If the user doesn't pass in a request id, one is auto-generated and that should get passed on to other services."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-08-05 10:46:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I would guess that part of the confusion here is that the report client is used from three (or is it four?[1]) different places, all of which are probably messing the context (in the generic sense, not the oslo sense) in different ways.

The intention of the request id is that an incoming use request gets an id (at the nova api level, usually) that is carried all way through the api server, the conductor, the scheduler, placement, back to the conductor, to the compute node, possibly back to placement again.

I agree that that doesn't happen but I'm not seeing a theory of operation to the fix being made here. This is "I found a more stable identifier, let's use that". Perhaps that's good enough, but it would be nice to actually understand what's going on, and to fix it in a way that is consistent with the original intent.

Another way to think about or query this is: What's special about the interactions with Placement that make it problematic. Is the fundamental problem that we sometimes send it the wrong (or even no) request id? Or something else?

We've theorized for some time that context is getting clobbered in some eventlet environments. How can we inspect that a bit more closely?

[1] nova-api, nova-conductor, nova-scheduler, nova-compute and it is not certain, from the associated description in the commit message that this is going to lead to consistent behavior from all those places.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-08-05 22:33:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2019-08-05 23:39:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-01 20:29:01.000000000', 'message': "Correct global_request_id sent to Placement

SchedulerReportClient methods invoke Placement APIs with the
X-Openstack-Request-Id header (via the global_request_id kwarg to SDK
Proxy methods) so that log entries on both sides can be correlated as
being associated with a single workflow.

Previously, SchedulerReportClient was using context.global_id of the
context passed in from the caller. This was (always? usually? often?) a
different RequestContext than the one in oslo.context's
threadlocal storage, which is the one oslo.log uses for logging. This
meant that the X-Openstack-Request-Id being sent to Placement was
worthless because it didn't show up *anywhere* in the logs on the Nova
side.

At some point to work around this problem a method
get_placement_request_id was written to extract the
X-Openstack-Request-Id from Placement's Response, and that request ID
was then being prepended to log messages. Since that value corresponded
to the Placement request's (not-global) request_id, which was being
logged properly on the Placement side, it provided a way to correlate
the log entries as desired.

What this commit does is to retrieve the global_id from the context in
oslo.context's threadlocal storage and use that for
X-Openstack-Request-Id instead. Since that is the request ID that Nova
is logging, and it then becomes Placement's global_request_id and
appears in the logs there, this allows proper correlation of the log
entries as intended.

Note that oslo.context's threadlocal context currently doesn't have a
global_request_id, so we're actually sending Nova's request_id across
the wire. But that shows up in the log, so it still works. A future
change will attempt to ensure that there's a proper global_request_id on
the Nova side, whereupon this flow will work (more) properly without
changes (since `.global_id` is a @property retrieving
`.global_request_id or .request_id`).

Change-Id: Ic1f4400aa30686b467d0dbef7f7dbd24b0124c71
"}, {'created': '2019-08-02 03:00:24.000000000', 'message': "Correct global_request_id sent to Placement

What this commit does is to retrieve the global_id from the context in

Note that oslo.context's threadlocal context currently doesn't have a

the Nova side, whereupon this flow will work (more) properly without

`.global_request_id or .request_id`).

Change-Id: Ic1f4400aa30686b467d0dbef7f7dbd24b0124c71
"}, {'created': '2019-08-05 22:33:14.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Correct global_request_id sent to Placement

SchedulerReportClient methods invoke Placement APIs with the
X-Openstack-Request-Id header (via the global_request_id kwarg to SDK
Proxy methods) so that log entries on both sides can be correlated as
being associated with a single workflow.

Previously, SchedulerReportClient was using context.global_id of the
context passed in from the caller. This was (always? usually? often?) a
different RequestContext than the one in oslo.context's
threadlocal storage, which is the one oslo.log uses for logging. This
meant that the X-Openstack-Request-Id being sent to Placement was
worthless because it didn't show up *anywhere* in the logs on the Nova
side.

At some point to work around this problem a method
get_placement_request_id was written to extract the
X-Openstack-Request-Id from Placement's Response, and that request ID
was then being prepended to log messages. Since that value corresponded
to the Placement request's (not-global) request_id, which was being
logged properly on the Placement side, it provided a way to correlate
the log entries as desired.

Since [1] we *should* be properly overwriting or *not* overwriting the
thread's RequestContext, and properly copying forward its
global_request_id regardless, so it should now be safe and effective to
use context.global_id for X-Openstack-Request-Id. However, I'm still not
confident this is working properly, so what this commit does is to
retrieve the global_id from the context in oslo.context's threadlocal
storage and compare it to context.global_id, issuing error logs if it
(the threadlocal one) is either unset or different from the one we
should be using. In the latter case, we'll use the threadlocal one so
that it's actually useful, but hopefully we should be able to get rid of
this.

[1] I47b48f661f4b3ebb1865357bce39610c4b26aeec

Change-Id: Ic1f4400aa30686b467d0dbef7f7dbd24b0124c71

storage and compare it to context.global_id, issuing error logs if it

Change-Id: Ic1f4400aa30686b467d0dbef7f7dbd24b0124c71
"}]
commit_message:
WIP: Correct global_request_id sent to Placement

SchedulerReportClient methods invoke Placement APIs with the
X-Openstack-Request-Id header (via the global_request_id kwarg to SDK
Proxy methods) so that log entries on both sides can be correlated as
being associated with a single workflow.

Previously, SchedulerReportClient was using context.global_id of the
context passed in from the caller. This was (always? usually? often?) a
different RequestContext than the one in oslo.context's
threadlocal storage, which is the one oslo.log uses for logging. This
meant that the X-Openstack-Request-Id being sent to Placement was
worthless because it didn't show up *anywhere* in the logs on the Nova
side.

At some point to work around this problem a method
get_placement_request_id was written to extract the
X-Openstack-Request-Id from Placement's Response, and that request ID
was then being prepended to log messages. Since that value corresponded
to the Placement request's (not-global) request_id, which was being
logged properly on the Placement side, it provided a way to correlate
the log entries as desired.

Since [1] we *should* be properly overwriting or *not* overwriting the
thread's RequestContext, and properly copying forward its
global_request_id regardless, so it should now be safe and effective to
use context.global_id for X-Openstack-Request-Id. However, I'm still not
confident this is working properly, so what this commit does is to
retrieve the global_id from the context in oslo.context's threadlocal
storage and compare it to context.global_id, issuing error logs if it
(the threadlocal one) is either unset or different from the one we
should be using. In the latter case, we'll use the threadlocal one so
that it's actually useful, but hopefully we should be able to get rid of
this.

[1] I47b48f661f4b3ebb1865357bce39610c4b26aeec

This needs a release note.
Also, I think Zhao tested doing a restart and it interrupts the flow of traffic through the load balancer. We should note that in the release note if that is in fact the case.'}, {'account_id': 29244, 'date': '2019-06-27 12:42:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> This needs a release note.
 > Also, I think Zhao tested doing a restart and it interrupts the
 > flow of traffic through the load balancer. We should note that in
 > the release note if that is in fact the case.

keepalived has an option:

        -I, --dont-release-ipvs
              Don't remove IPVS topology on daemon stop. The default behavior it to remove all entries from the IPVS virtual server table when keepalived exits.

It would avoid traffic interruption but then we should find a way to remove IPVS configuration where removing a listener (reload with an empty configuration, then exit?)"}, {'account_id': 29244, 'date': '2019-06-28 07:05:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 29244, 'date': '2019-06-28 07:07:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

commit_message:
Fixed down server issue after reloading keepalived

When removing a UDP health monitor, keepalived is reloaded with a
configuration without any checkers.
But if keepalived has previously detected a down server, the state of
the server is unchanged and it will never be added to the list of IPVS
servers.

Restarting keepalived on configuration change works around this issue.

This issue is fixed in keepalived (>=2.0.14):
https://github.com/acassen/keepalived/issues/1163

Story: 2005774
Task: 33491

Change-Id: Iaa34db6cb1dfed98e96a585c5d105e263c7efa65

commit_message:
Use new kolla-ansible upgrade-bifrost command

This command slightly modifies the deploy operation to first stop the
bifrost services and container if they are running.

Change-Id: If0fe1115f01738254a61c0f5460548b0d6ae6b9a
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/667630
Story: 2006050
Task: 34743

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-07 08:49:15.000000000', 'message': 'Trivial: Remove duplicate usage of db context

The change to use cache in Trait object [1] moved the raw database
query to deeper layer from ids_from_names() function, but it was
still decorated with the db context manager, so this patch removes it.

[1] Ia19ea2b4ecdde25323579edf60ad6269d05e75a2

Change-Id: Ic39d9c65c1c15401da81725491090149d3c430ec
'}]
commit_message:
Trivial: Remove duplicate usage of db context

The change to use cache in Trait object [1] moved the raw database
query to deeper layer from ids_from_names() function, but it was
still decorated with the db context manager, so this patch removes it.

[1] Ia19ea2b4ecdde25323579edf60ad6269d05e75a2

Change-Id: Ic39d9c65c1c15401da81725491090149d3c430ec

commit_message:
Skip some tests in "network.admin.test_ports" if nova is not enabled

Some tests in "tempest.api.network.admin.test_ports" need to enable nova
service, skip them if nova service is not enabled.

Change-Id: I58bdb453052286a152a008bc1a51cc9eb34ce821
Closes-Bug: #1763620

[{'created': '2018-08-23 16:54:18.000000000', 'message': "neutron-api: move /usr/share/neutron mount

We don't need to mount /usr/share/neutron in neutron_db_sync container,
the directory doesn't exist and isn't needed.
Instead, mount it at step4 in the neutron_api container where we
actually need it, and where the directory is here already.

With podman, the dirs that don't exist and are being mounted aren't
created like it's the case with Docker.

commit_message:
neutron-api: remove /usr/share/neutron mount

We don't need to mount /usr/share/neutron, the directory is provided in
openstack-neutron rpm, so we don't need to manage this directory. It
should be in all neutron containers, including the neutron_db_sync.

Change-Id: I6f71ce62b1c5f3de175d7a50ee7229d3047a379a

commit_message:
Do not try to use zRAM devices for anything

These devices are mapped into memory, but nonetheless can appear
in lsblk output. Ignore them explicitly.

Change-Id: I2bb595ef29abdc98bd887bdf41c3c7f64cc3a7e6

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-07 14:13:37.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure that keystone service is paused if needed on series upgrade

During series upgrade, the keystone packages get re-installed as the
underlying Linux has been upgraded and new package sets are updated and
then pulled in.  For trusty->xenial this means that keystone.service
gets enabled which then breaks haproxy.  On install, on xenial+, the
keystone.service is disabled in the install hook.  This just replicates
this in the series-upgrade hook.

Change-Id: Ic5ed6cf354d5545b9e554e205a048955a381e0f5
Closed-Bug: #1839021
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure that keystone service is paused if needed on series upgrade

During series upgrade, the keystone packages get re-installed as the
underlying Linux has been upgraded and new package sets are updated and
then pulled in.  For trusty->xenial this means that keystone.service
gets enabled which then breaks haproxy.  On install, on xenial+, the
keystone.service is disabled in the install hook.  This just replicates
this in the series-upgrade hook.

Change-Id: Ic5ed6cf354d5545b9e554e205a048955a381e0f5
Closed-Bug: #1839021

[{'created': '2019-08-04 17:56:11.000000000', 'message': "Generate bifrost hostvars prior to provisioning

The 'kayobe overcloud inventory discover' command can be used to discover an
overcloud inventory from the nodes in the ironic service running on the seed.
This works well for cases where the nodes have been autodiscovered, and as such
do not exist in the kayobe inventory.

There is another use case where overcloud nodes already exist in the kayobe
inventory. In that case we don't want to run the above command, as it will
create duplicate hosts in the inventory. We do however want the part of that
command that generates bifrost host variables for the overcloud nodes.

This change moves the generation of bifrost host variables to the 'kayobe
overcloud provision' and 'kayobe overcloud hardware inspect' commands,
which are used in each of these cases.

"}]
commit_message:
Generate bifrost hostvars prior to provisioning

The 'kayobe overcloud inventory discover' command can be used to discover an
overcloud inventory from the nodes in the ironic service running on the seed.
This works well for cases where the nodes have been autodiscovered, and as such
do not exist in the kayobe inventory.

There is another use case where overcloud nodes already exist in the kayobe
inventory. In that case we don't want to run the above command, as it will
create duplicate hosts in the inventory. We do however want the part of that
command that generates bifrost host variables for the overcloud nodes.

This change moves the generation of bifrost host variables to the 'kayobe
overcloud provision' and 'kayobe overcloud hardware inspect' commands,
which are used in each of these cases.

Conflicts:
	kayobe/tests/unit/cli/test_commands.py

Change-Id: I8a69ccd5192c0c5beeb7efb36c09b2c4643ef150
Story: 2004426
Task: 28079
(cherry picked from commit bff985330af53f65b2ff2328acb76a835866387b)

commit_message:
remove Tony's name as naming poll coordinator

Tony has indicated in the review for
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/674465/ that he would prefer to have
his name removed as polling coordinator.

Add Rico, who volunteer to be naming poll coordinator

Change-Id: I4dd637d0db02b7ecbd9c2d2a63827f11afa93efb
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

[{'created': '2017-07-05 13:53:11.000000000', 'message': 'Fix regression with container_name var

As of I56d8afddbccf01f2944d2fdd505b601a4b048374 the container_name
var is no longer referenced by the strategy plugin to identify the
name of the LXC container on the physical host. Instead, only
inventory_hostname is referenced.

The regression breaks cases where the container_name may not match
the inventory_hostname var. This fix repairs the strategy plugin to
again reference the container_name var, and performs the required
templating lookup to ensure container_name="{{ inventory_hostname }}"
is resolved properly.

commit_message:
Fix regression with container_name var

As of I56d8afddbccf01f2944d2fdd505b601a4b048374 the container_name
var is no longer referenced by the strategy plugin to identify the
name of the LXC container on the physical host. Instead, only
inventory_hostname is referenced.

The regression breaks cases where the container_name may not match
the inventory_hostname var. This fix repairs the strategy plugin to
again reference the container_name var, and performs the required
templating lookup to ensure container_name="{{ inventory_hostname }}"
is resolved properly.

Change-Id: I0c2815c4257298ed60d44e48cbbfe7cd405e5955

commit_message:
Reverting changes from commit 69a6fde

This patch reverts the non-charmhelpers changes from
the patch landed for bug 1835045 that is causing a
regression whereby new deployments that relate to
ceph-mon are prevented from sending broker requests
to do e.g. create the pool needed by
libvirt-image-backend=rbd.

Change-Id: I29421ce240a3810d945b76e662a743b4b8497ac8
Related-Bug: 1835045
Closes-Bug: 1839297

commit_message:
Change HOST_IP to SERVICE_HOST

HOST_IP is only for ipv4,
SERVICE_HOST can fit for ipv4 and ipv6.
IPV6 log can check here:
http://logs.openstack.org/51/673751/1/check/murano-tempest-api-ipv6-only/f947d0e/job-output.txt.gz#_2019-07-31_08_54_25_077300

Change-Id: I7574a273e1c0511c56370b2203694dc52d963afc

commit_message:
solidfire: Enable SSL with requests

SSL requests are not being verified when contacting
the REST API. Use the driver_ssl_cert_verify
config option to turn on or off. Defaults to False.

Change-Id: Ib64c86fa5e3791dfa5386b58b468a91f1a190de6
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chucks@redhat.com>

subject: Add dedicated auth endpoint config for virtual machines
messages:
[{'account_id': 29865, 'date': '2019-03-12 16:22:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-03-12 17:13:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)

Looks like a good start. Some comments inline.'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-03-13 03:43:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-03-13 04:04:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1 -Workflow'}, {'account_id': 29865, 'date': '2019-03-13 17:07:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 29865, 'date': '2019-03-13 17:14:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

From what I've seen today, auth_url in _get_heat_signal_credentials of   signal_responder and in the elif self.transport_zaqar_message(props) branch of _populate_deployments_metadata(self, meta, props) in server_base.py both need the version of the end point specified, while in the if self.transport_poll_server_heat(props) branch in server_base.py it doesn't seem to matter. Our aim is to backport this patch so I'm not so keen to go writing a function."}, {'account_id': 29865, 'date': '2019-03-13 17:20:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-03-14 05:22:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

>  while in the if self.transport_poll_server_heat(props) branch in server_base.py it doesn't seem to matter

It depends on what you use for

1. software_config_transport property of Server resource for polling metadata

2. signal_transport property of SoftwareDeployment Resource for signaling

If you use  POLL_SERVER_CFN/POLL_TEMP_URL for polling metdata or CFN_SIGNAL/TEMP_URL_SIGNAL for signaling, you won't need this change.

Looks like magnum is using POLL_SERVER_HEAT for software_config_transport[1] by default. May be you're using ZAQAR_MESSAGE as the metadata transport, hence the behaviour you described above.

Also, please file a story/task and add it to commit message as we plan to backport it.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/magnum/blob/master/magnum/drivers/k8s_fedora_ironic_v1/templates/kubemaster.yaml#L506"}, {'account_id': 29865, 'date': '2019-03-18 11:29:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 29865, 'date': '2019-03-18 11:29:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 29865, 'date': '2019-03-18 11:31:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> Also, please file a story/task and add it to commit message as we
 > plan to backport it.

Linked to https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2004808'}, {'account_id': 29865, 'date': '2019-03-18 11:42:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-03-20 09:02:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-03-20 20:41:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)

We discussed this a bit in the meeting today:

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/heat/2019/heat.2019-03-20-14.00.log.html#l-98

(it runs into the next topic a bit).

Open questions:

* I've elaborated on one inline
* Could you please add a release note for this? (See https://docs.openstack.org/reno/latest/user/usage.html for instructions.) This will help users who need this feature determine when it made it into the various stable branch releases. The note should probably go in the 'fixes' section.
* Earlier you wrote:

> Our aim is to backport this patch so I'm not so keen to go writing a function.

I don't really see the connection here, and in fact - speaking as the only active stable-branch maintainer ;) - I'd prefer to see something that is maintainable in the long term backported."}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-03-20 20:54:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> > Our aim is to backport this patch so I'm not so keen to go
 > writing a function.
 > 
 > I don't really see the connection here, and in fact - speaking as
 > the only active stable-branch maintainer ;) - I'd prefer to see
 > something that is maintainable in the long term backported.

We assumed that the request to add a function was to wrap up the "take new config option in preference to original behaviour" neatly in one place.

There are three places in the code that we have touched, two originally used self.context.auth_url and one uses self.keystone().v3_endpoint. If we were to factor out a function then we'd have to choose one of these as the "fallback" over the config option, which felt like it introduced a reasonable risk of changing the existing behaviour. We're not sufficiently familiar with the distinction between self.keystone().v3_endpoint and self.context.auth_url to be able to make that call.'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-03-20 21:08:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29865, 'date': '2019-03-21 11:36:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow-1

Just going to put a hold on this while we look at the alternatives.'}, {'account_id': 29865, 'date': '2019-04-12 12:44:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 29865, 'date': '2019-04-12 13:17:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7: Patch Set 6 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 29865, 'date': '2019-08-07 16:15:05.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Add dedicated auth endpoint config for virtual machines

This addresses some of the issues discussed here:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-February/002925.html

Clarification of the keystone endpoint handling can be in a
different patch. This leaves the current behavior unaffected.

Change-Id: Ie4071c904fcf4756bc840beb98ebe80e2b838423

commit_message:
Use expanding bindparam in extend_usages_by_provider_tree

When doing a non-nested GET /allocation_candidates query, the
`in_` handling in extend_usages_by_provider_tree is a measurable
contributor to CPU time, so we lighten that somewhat with an
expanding bindparam, as done early in provider_ids_from_rp_ids [1]

[1] Ic4e0cdd87f8f2d76b921059ac4bf16a838913abf

Change-Id: I121e5ac6e8202467bf72d9de7ac452d5b5804da1

commit_message:
Make _get_trees_with_traits return a set

The docstring says it returns a set, but it is a list. The output
is immediately used for membership checking in filter_by_rp. Sets
are better for membership checking, so we'd like this to be a set.

Change-Id: I202f6114648a69a3bf54fe2c3a67b5cab55e8925

Is it possible to tell the difference from the job results?'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-07-30 16:58:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Is it possible to tell the difference from the job results?

not directly. you can see how long it takes here: https://opendev.org/openstack/placement/src/commit/2f56f379a568d427ac9057086386074a7801b00c/placement/objects/resource_class.py#L72

and I suspect that analysing the placement-api.log would show some different patterns. Compare the first few requests of http://logs.openstack.org/67/670567/3/check/placement-nested-perfload/fc76783/logs/placement-api.log with http://logs.openstack.org/67/670567/3/check/placement-nested-perfload/fc76783/logs/placement-api.log

In the latter (this patch) there are several POST to create resource providers at the same time.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-30 17:07:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

assume that second link was supposed to be

http://logs.openstack.org/05/673505/1/check/placement-nested-perfload/5b008b3/logs/placement-api.log

And "at the same time" is "within the order of 10ms vs 100ms of each other" which, while not probative, is at least somewhat convincing.

I suppose if we logged thread IDs as well as process IDs it might be clearer?

Anyway, this isn't breaking anything, so I see no harm in merging it.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-07-31 10:19:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2019-08-06 05:13:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

-1 because we need to update the doc accordingly.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-08-06 08:02:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

See, not only can Tetsuro write better English than the natives, he can also read it...

I'll make some adjustments. 

Thank you!"}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-08-06 08:19:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-08-06 08:23:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I've decided to try to share gabbi-run's cpu usage with the web server and database a bit more fairly, and gone for 50%. This makes sense based on the manual testing I did last week, but we can compare the numbers...

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-30 12:49:26.000000000', 'message': "Run nested-perfload parallel correctly

While experimenting with expanding the nested perfload tests,
it became clear that the call to parallel was not working as
documented. What's supposed to be happening is that 3*nprocs
processes are run, but in local testing that's not what happens:
instead just one, in sequence.

This changes it to use available processors.

Subsequent patches will add a more complicated nested structure.

Change-Id: Ie4809abc31212711b96f69e5f291104ae761059e
"}, {'created': '2019-07-31 10:19:30.000000000', 'message': "Run nested-perfload parallel correctly

While experimenting with expanding the nested perfload tests,
it became clear that the call to parallel was not working as
documented. What's supposed to be happening is that 3*nprocs
processes are run, but in local testing that's not what happens:
instead just one, in sequence.

This changes it to use available processors.

Subsequent patches will add a more complicated nested structure.

Change-Id: Ie4809abc31212711b96f69e5f291104ae761059e
"}, {'created': '2019-08-06 08:19:01.000000000', 'message': 'Run nested-perfload parallel correctly

While experimenting with expanding the nested perfload tests,
it became clear that the call to parallel was not working as
expected because the documents were misread. With help from
Tetsuro the correct incantation was determined so that we
use 50% of available CPUs.

This should leave some space for the database and the web
server.

Subsequent patches will add a more complicated nested structure.

Co-Authored-By: Tetsuro Nakamura <tetsuro.nakamura.bc@hco.ntt.co.jp>
Change-Id: Ie4809abc31212711b96f69e5f291104ae761059e

commit_message:
Run nested-perfload parallel correctly

While experimenting with expanding the nested perfload tests,
it became clear that the call to parallel was not working as
expected because the documents were misread. With help from
Tetsuro the correct incantation was determined so that we
use 50% of available CPUs.

This should leave some space for the database and the web
server.

Subsequent patches will add a more complicated nested structure.

Co-Authored-By: Tetsuro Nakamura <tetsuro.nakamura.bc@hco.ntt.co.jp>
Change-Id: Ie4809abc31212711b96f69e5f291104ae761059e

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-25 13:31:38.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "[libvirt] Filter hypervisor_type by virt_type"

This reverts commit eaa766ee2093c24fd61c61e52f46bdd9ff9e93d2.

The change regressed the behavior of the ImagePropertiesFilter
because existing images with hypervisor_type=QEMU, which would
match what is reported for hypervisor_type in the API for both
qemu/kvm virt_type nodes, will now get filtered out for hosts
where the configured virt_type is kvm.

Note that both the ImagePropertiesFilter docs [1] and
hypervisor_type image property docs [2] mention that for both
qemu and kvm nodes the value to use is qemu since that is the
actual hypervisor.

Presumably the change was made for a deployment with some
hosts configured with virt_type=qemu and other hosts configured
with virt_type=kvm and there were separate images with
hypervisor_type=qemu and hypervisor_type=kvm to match those hosts
for scheduler filter, but as noted this was a regression in
behavior for something that could have been achieved using
host aggregates and the AggregateImagePropertiesIsolation filter.

We could even use traits and a placement request pre-filter these
days for a more modern approach.

Also, since the API continues to report hypervisor_type=QEMU it's
doubly confusing for operators to have to configure their images
to use hypervisor_type=kvm (despite the docs).

And finally, any existing instances which have hypervisor_type=qemu
embedded in their RequestSpec can no longer be migrated to kvm
hosts without manually fixing the entries in the request_specs
table in the API DB.

Note that this is not a clean revert because of change
I5d95bd50279a6bf903a5793ad5f3ae9d06f085f4 made in Stein.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/configuration/schedulers.html#imagepropertiesfilter
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/glance/latest/admin/useful-image-properties.html

Change-Id: I7d761dc269f8c12c4a76ba14201ccdd82a04d01d
Closes-Bug: #1837756
(cherry picked from commit 743dc083bb5628554d9abfa82665738233ed47e9)
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "[libvirt] Filter hypervisor_type by virt_type"

This reverts commit eaa766ee2093c24fd61c61e52f46bdd9ff9e93d2.

The change regressed the behavior of the ImagePropertiesFilter
because existing images with hypervisor_type=QEMU, which would
match what is reported for hypervisor_type in the API for both
qemu/kvm virt_type nodes, will now get filtered out for hosts
where the configured virt_type is kvm.

Note that both the ImagePropertiesFilter docs [1] and
hypervisor_type image property docs [2] mention that for both
qemu and kvm nodes the value to use is qemu since that is the
actual hypervisor.

Presumably the change was made for a deployment with some
hosts configured with virt_type=qemu and other hosts configured
with virt_type=kvm and there were separate images with
hypervisor_type=qemu and hypervisor_type=kvm to match those hosts
for scheduler filter, but as noted this was a regression in
behavior for something that could have been achieved using
host aggregates and the AggregateImagePropertiesIsolation filter.

We could even use traits and a placement request pre-filter these
days for a more modern approach.

Also, since the API continues to report hypervisor_type=QEMU it's
doubly confusing for operators to have to configure their images
to use hypervisor_type=kvm (despite the docs).

And finally, any existing instances which have hypervisor_type=qemu
embedded in their RequestSpec can no longer be migrated to kvm
hosts without manually fixing the entries in the request_specs
table in the API DB.

Note that this is not a clean revert because of change
I5d95bd50279a6bf903a5793ad5f3ae9d06f085f4 made in Stein.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/configuration/schedulers.html#imagepropertiesfilter
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/glance/latest/admin/useful-image-properties.html

Change-Id: I7d761dc269f8c12c4a76ba14201ccdd82a04d01d
Closes-Bug: #1837756
(cherry picked from commit 743dc083bb5628554d9abfa82665738233ed47e9)
